1.name: Awareness
1.description: You're exploring entrepreneurship and business fundamentals
capabilities: Recognize that ideas are cheap, execution is everything
1.milestone: Interview 5 potential customers about their problems

2.name: Explorer
2.milestone: Get someone to pay you for something (even $1)

3.name: Builder
3.description: Building your first real business or product
3.milestone: Launch a product and get 10 paying customers

4.name: Revenue Generator
4.description: Consistently generating revenue from your business

5.name: Systems Builder
5.description: Building systems that reduce your direct involvement
capabilities: Hire first team members or contractors
5.milestone: Business runs for a week without you

6.name: Scale Artist
6.description: Scaling what works, eliminating what doesn't

7.name: Strategic Thinker
7.description: Thinking strategically about moats and competitive advantage

8.name: Business Leader
8.description: Leading a real company with team and culture
8.milestone: Team operates effectively without daily oversight

9.name: Visionary
9.description: Creating something that changes your industry
capabilities: Set long-term vision others rally behind
Make bold bets that pay off
9.milestone: Your business meaningfully impacts your industry

10.name: Business Master
10.description: Building legendary businesses or teaching others to do so
10.milestone: Your business thinking influences how others build

beginner.title: Problem Interview Sprint
beginner.instructions: Talk to 5 people in a target market. Ask: What's your biggest challenge with [topic]? What have you tried? How much does this cost you? Take notes. Don't pitch - just learn.

beginner.title: Idea Validation Scorecard
beginner.instructions: Take your business idea. Score it on: Market size (1-10), Personal interest (1-10), Problem severity (1-10), Ability to reach customers (1-10), Competitive landscape (1-10). Multiply scores.

beginner.title: First Principles Problem Analysis
beginner.instructions: Pick a problem you want to solve. List every assumption about how it's currently solved. For each assumption, ask 'Why?' until you hit fundamental truths. Look for hidden opportunities.
beginner.success_criteria: Written analysis with at least one non-obvious insight

intermediate.title: Pre-Sell Your Offer
intermediate.instructions: Before building anything, create a landing page or offer document. Try to get 3 people to commit (deposit, letter of intent, or strong verbal). If you can't sell it, don't build it.
intermediate.success_criteria: Landing page live with at least 1 signup or commitment

intermediate.title: Customer Discovery Interview Deep Dive
intermediate.instructions: Conduct 3 in-depth customer interviews (30 min each). Use the Mom Test principles: no pitching, ask about past behavior not future intentions, understand their workflow.
intermediate.success_criteria: 3 detailed interview transcripts with actionable insights

intermediate.title: Unit Economics Calculator
intermediate.instructions: Calculate: Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC), Lifetime Value (LTV), Payback Period, Gross Margin. Is LTV > 3x CAC? Can you afford the payback period?
intermediate.success_criteria: Complete unit economics with decision about viability

advanced.title: Build Your Competitive Moat
advanced.instructions: Identify which moats you could build: network effects, switching costs, brand, scale, technology, data, regulatory. Pick 2 to focus on. Create a plan to strengthen them.
advanced.success_criteria: Moat strategy document with 6-month action plan

advanced.title: Contrarian Truth Discovery
advanced.instructions: Ask yourself Peter Thiel's question: 'What important truth do very few people agree with you on?' As it relates to your industry, what do you believe that would be controversial?
advanced.success_criteria: Written contrarian thesis with supporting logic

advanced.title: Business Model Canvas
advanced.instructions: Complete a full business model canvas: Customer Segments, Value Propositions, Channels, Customer Relationships, Revenue Streams, Key Resources, Key Activities, Key Partners, Cost Structure.
advanced.success_criteria: Completed canvas with all 9 sections filled and validated

cross_module_connections.insight: A business without sales is a hobby. Your ability to sell determines your ceiling.
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: This week, personally sell to 10 potential customers. Learn what objections arise and how to handle them.

cross_module_connections.insight: Business is the fastest path to wealth - it's the vehicle, personal finance is just the maintenance.
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: Calculate: If this business works, what's your potential equity value in 5 years? Use that to motivate through hard times.

cross_module_connections.insight: Entrepreneurship is a mental game - resilience matters more than brilliance.
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: List 10 things that could go wrong. For each, write 'If X happens, I will Y.' Pre-decide your responses.

cross_module_connections.insight: As a founder, your time is your most constrained resource - ruthless prioritization is survival.
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: List everything you do in your business. Circle the 3 things only you can do. Delegate or eliminate the rest.

masters.name: Elon Musk
key_principles: First principles thinking: Boil things down to fundamental truths and reason up from there.
If something is important enough, you do it even if the odds are not in your favor.
Failure is an option here. If things are not failing, you are not innovating enough.
Work like hell. 80-100 hour weeks every week.
When something is important enough, you do it even if the odds are not in your favor.
Constantly think about how you could be doing things better.
daily_practices: Work on the hardest problem first

worked_examples.title: First Principles for Cost Reduction
worked_examples.scenario: Your product costs too much to be competitive. The industry says 'that's just what things cost.'
step_by_step: List every component of your cost
For each, ask: Why does this cost this much?
Break down to raw materials/fundamentals
What would this cost if we rebuilt from scratch?
Identify where convention adds unnecessary cost
Rebuild the solution from fundamentals
Achieve 10x cost reduction by ignoring 'how it's always been done'
worked_examples.outcome: SpaceX reduced rocket launch costs by 10x by manufacturing in-house what others outsourced, simply by reasoning from first principles.

scripts_templates.title: First Principles Problem Analysis
scripts_templates.context: Use when industry convention says something is impossible or too expensive
scripts_templates.template:
PROBLEM: ___

CONVENTIONAL WISDOM SAYS: ___

BREAK DOWN TO FUNDAMENTALS:
1. What are the basic elements required?
   - ___
   - ___
   - ___

2. What do these fundamentally cost?
   - ___
   - ___
   - ___

3. Where does convention add unnecessary cost/complexity?
   - ___
   - ___

4. If we rebuilt from scratch, what would it look like?
   - ___

NEW SOLUTION: ___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
PROBLEM: Batteries for EVs cost too much

CONVENTIONAL WISDOM: Batteries cost $600/kWh, that's just the market

BREAK DOWN TO FUNDAMENTALS:
1. Basic elements: Lithium, cobalt, nickel, aluminum, steel, polymers
2. Raw material cost: ~$80/kWh
3. Convention adds:
   - Multiple middlemen marking up
   - Inefficient cell design
   - Over-engineering for old use cases

4. From scratch:
   - Vertically integrate supply chain
   - Redesign cell format for EV-specific needs
   - Scale manufacturing radically

NEW SOLUTION: Target $100/kWh through vertical integration and new cell design

books.title: Elon Musk (Biography)
books.author: Ashlee Vance
books.key_takeaway: The mindset and methods behind building multiple revolutionary companies

books.title: Elon Musk (Biography)
books.author: Walter Isaacson
books.key_takeaway: Updated look at Musk's approach to innovation and management

podcasts.title: Elon Musk on Lex Fridman
podcasts.key_takeaway: Deep dive into first principles thinking and company building

masters.name: Jeff Bezos
masters.expertise: Long-term thinking, customer obsession, Day 1 mentality
key_principles: Focus on customers, not competitors.
It's always Day 1. Day 2 is stasis, followed by death.
Make high-velocity decisions. Most decisions are reversible.
Invent on behalf of customers. They won't tell you what they need.
Your margin is my opportunity.
If you never want to be criticized, for goodness' sake don't do anything new.
daily_practices: Start with the customer and work backwards
Make decisions with 70% of information needed

worked_examples.title: Working Backwards from the Customer
worked_examples.scenario: You have a product idea but aren't sure if customers actually want it.
step_by_step: Write the press release first: What would the announcement say?
Write the FAQ: What questions would customers and internal teams ask?
Define the customer experience: Walk through every touchpoint
If you can't write a compelling press release, the idea isn't clear enough
Use the FAQ to identify risks and unknowns
Build only after the narrative is crisp
This prevents building things nobody wants
worked_examples.outcome: Amazon uses this for every new product. It forces clarity on customer value before engineering begins.

scripts_templates.title: PR/FAQ Template (Working Backwards)
scripts_templates.context: Use before building any new product or feature
scripts_templates.template:
[INTERNAL PRESS RELEASE]

Headline: ___
Subhead: One sentence describing the customer and benefit

Problem: What problem does this solve? (2-3 sentences)

Solution: How does the product solve it? (2-3 sentences)

Quote from leader: Why we're excited about this

How it works: Simple explanation a customer would understand

Customer quote: What would a happy customer say?

Call to action: How to get started

[FAQ - EXTERNAL]
1. What is this?
2. Why should I care?
3. How does it work?
4. What does it cost?
5. How is it different from alternatives?

[FAQ - INTERNAL]
1. Why will this succeed?
2. What are the biggest risks?
3. What's the hardest part to build?
4. What resources do we need?
5. How will we measure success?
scripts_templates.example_filled:
HEADLINE: SmartReceipt Eliminates Expense Report Hassle

SUBHEAD: Business travelers can now snap a photo of receipts and have expense reports filed automatically.

PROBLEM: Business travelers spend 2+ hours monthly on expense reports, a task everyone hates and often delays reimbursement.

SOLUTION: SmartReceipt uses AI to read receipts, categorize expenses, and file compliant reports - all from a phone photo.

QUOTE: 'We believe no one should spend their Sunday night organizing receipts.' - Product Lead

HOW IT WORKS: Take photo → AI extracts data → Auto-files to your company's system

CUSTOMER QUOTE: 'I went from 2 hours to 2 minutes. I just take photos and forget about it.'

CTA: Download the app and connect your corporate account.

books.title: The Everything Store
books.author: Brad Stone
books.key_takeaway: How Bezos built Amazon through customer obsession and long-term thinking

books.title: Working Backwards
books.author: Colin Bryar & Bill Carr
books.key_takeaway: Amazon's internal practices from former executives

podcasts.title: Bezos Annual Letters
podcasts.key_takeaway: Read all shareholder letters for pure strategic thinking

masters.name: Peter Thiel
masters.expertise: Contrarian thinking, monopolies, zero to one
key_principles: Competition is for losers. Build a monopoly.
The best investment in a portfolio equals or outperforms the rest combined.
What important truth do very few people agree with you on?
Going from 0 to 1 is harder and more valuable than 1 to N.
A startup messed up at its foundation cannot be fixed.
The most contrarian thing is not to oppose the crowd but to think for yourself.
daily_practices: Ask: What's a belief I hold that most people disagree with?
Build something 10x better, not incrementally better
Focus resources on the one thing that matters most

worked_examples.title: Finding Your Contrarian Truth
worked_examples.scenario: You want to build a startup but every idea seems to already exist.
step_by_step: Ask: What important truth do very few people agree with you on?
Your answer should be something that most people disagree with but you believe is true
A good answer takes the form: 'Most people believe X, but the truth is the opposite of X'
Your contrarian truth becomes your startup thesis
Build for the world where your contrarian truth is right
If you're right, you have a monopoly. If everyone agreed, there would be competition.
worked_examples.outcome: PayPal succeeded because Thiel believed: 'Most people think payments are solved by banks. The truth is the internet will create entirely new payment systems.'

scripts_templates.title: Contrarian Truth Discovery Template
scripts_templates.context: Use to find unique startup opportunities others are missing
scripts_templates.template:
THE QUESTION:
What important truth do very few people agree with me on?

CONVENTIONAL WISDOM IN MY INDUSTRY:
1. Most people believe: ___
2. Most people believe: ___
3. Most people believe: ___

MY CONTRARIAN TRUTHS:
1. But I believe: ___
   Evidence: ___
2. But I believe: ___
   Evidence: ___
3. But I believe: ___
   Evidence: ___

BUSINESS IMPLICATION:
If my contrarian truth #___ is right, the opportunity is: ___

MONOPOLY POTENTIAL:
If I'm right and others are wrong, I will be the only one building for this reality.
scripts_templates.example_filled:
CONVENTIONAL WISDOM IN AI:
1. Most believe: AI will replace human workers
2. Most believe: The best AI products need the most data
3. Most believe: AI is only for big tech companies

MY CONTRARIAN TRUTHS:
1. AI will augment humans, not replace them. Evidence: Every past automation created more jobs.
2. The best AI products need domain expertise, not just data. Evidence: Specialized models outperform general ones.
3. The biggest AI opportunities are in boring industries. Evidence: Less competition, more inefficiency.

BUSINESS IMPLICATION:
If #3 is right, the opportunity is: AI for small business accounting, plumbing scheduling, etc.

MONOPOLY: While everyone fights for consumer AI, I build for plumbers who've been ignored.

books.title: Zero to One
books.author: Peter Thiel
books.key_takeaway: Notes on startups, or how to build the future

books.title: The Diversity Myth
books.author: Peter Thiel
books.key_takeaway: Early contrarian thinking from his Stanford days

podcasts.title: Peter Thiel on Tim Ferriss
podcasts.key_takeaway: Deep dive into contrarian thinking and company building

masters.name: Paul Graham
key_principles: Make something people want.
Launch fast and iterate.
Talk to users. Build what they need.
Do things that don't scale in the beginning.
The best founders have a chip on their shoulder.
If you're not embarrassed by your first version, you launched too late.
daily_practices: Talk to at least one user/customer today
Focus on making something people actually want

worked_examples.title: Doing Things That Don't Scale
worked_examples.scenario: You're building a startup and worried about efficiency and automation from day one.
step_by_step: Forget about scale initially - first, prove people want it
Recruit users one by one: email, call, visit them personally
Provide white-glove service: do things manually that you'll later automate
Airbnb founders personally photographed listings, Stripe founders installed their SDK on laptops
Use the manual effort to learn what to build
Only automate after you understand the process perfectly
Early inefficiency = learning. Premature optimization = death.
worked_examples.outcome: By doing things manually first, you learn what really matters before investing in automation that might be wrong.

scripts_templates.title: Customer Discovery Interview Script (The Mom Test)
scripts_templates.context: Learn what customers really need without pitching or biasing their answers
scripts_templates.template:
RULES:
- Don't mention your idea until the end
- Ask about their life, not your idea
- Ask about the past, not the future
- Talk less, listen more

OPENING:
'I'm trying to understand how [domain] works for people like you.'

CORE QUESTIONS:
1. 'Walk me through the last time you [did the thing]...'
2. 'What was the hardest part?'
3. 'Why was that hard?'
4. 'What have you tried to solve that?'
5. 'What didn't work about those solutions?'
6. 'How much does this problem cost you (time/money/stress)?'
7. 'Have you looked for a solution in the last [month]?'

CLOSING:
'I'm actually working on something in this space. Can I tell you about it and get your honest reaction?'

AFTER:
- Would they pay for it? Ask for commitment.
- Would they use it? Ask for specific next step.
scripts_templates.example_filled:
DOMAIN: Expense reports for business travelers

OPENING: 'I'm trying to understand how expense reports work for people who travel for work.'

1. 'Walk me through the last time you filed an expense report...'
   -> 'I had a pile of receipts from my trip, spent 2 hours Sunday night sorting them...'

2. 'What was the hardest part?'
   -> 'Matching receipts to transactions and categorizing everything correctly'

3. 'Why was that hard?'
   -> 'Our system has 50 categories and I never know which one to use'

4. 'What have you tried?'
   -> 'I tried an app but it didn't integrate with our system'

5. 'What didn't work?'
   -> 'Still had to manually enter everything twice'

6. 'What does this cost you?'
   -> '2-3 hours monthly, plus delayed reimbursements'

7. 'Looked for solutions recently?'
   -> 'Googled last month but gave up'

books.title: Paul Graham Essays
books.author: Paul Graham (paulgraham.com)
books.key_takeaway: The collected wisdom of YC's founder - must-read for any founder

books.title: Hackers & Painters
books.author: Paul Graham
books.key_takeaway: Essays on creativity, startups, and making things

podcasts.title: How to Start a Startup (YC)
podcasts.key_takeaway: Stanford course with Paul Graham and other YC partners

masters.name: Sam Altman
key_principles: Compounding is magic. Long-term thinking wins.
It's easier to do a hard startup than an easy startup.
The most important thing is to build something people want.
Great execution is at least 10x more important than a great idea.
Hire slowly, fire quickly.
Focus is a force multiplier.
daily_practices: Make yourself a force multiplier for your team

worked_examples.title: Choosing a Hard Problem Over an Easy One
worked_examples.scenario: You're deciding between a simple app and a technically challenging project.
step_by_step: Recognize: Easy problems attract more competition
Hard problems (technical, regulatory, coordination) create natural moats
Recruiting is easier for hard problems - great people want meaningful challenges
Investors are more interested in hard problems - higher potential returns
Easy startups feel easy at first, then get brutally hard (competition)
Hard startups feel hard at first, then get easier (moats compound)
Choose the hard problem you're uniquely positioned to solve
worked_examples.outcome: OpenAI chose the 'impossible' problem of AGI. That hard choice attracted world-class talent and eliminated most competition.

scripts_templates.title: Startup Idea Evaluation Framework
scripts_templates.context: Evaluate whether a startup idea is worth pursuing
scripts_templates.template:
IDEA: ___

MARKET SIZE:
- How big is this market? ___
- Is it growing? ___

PROBLEM SEVERITY:
- How painful is this problem? (1-10) ___
- How often do people experience it? ___
- Are people actively looking for solutions? ___

SOLUTION QUALITY:
- Is this 10x better than alternatives? ___
- Why hasn't this been built before? ___

FOUNDER-MARKET FIT:
- Why are you uniquely suited to solve this? ___
- What do you know that others don't? ___

EXECUTION COMPLEXITY:
- Is this a hard startup or an easy one? ___
- What makes it defensible? ___

FINAL ASSESSMENT:
- Would I work on this for 10 years? ___
- Score: ___ / 50
scripts_templates.example_filled:
IDEA: AI-powered legal document review

MARKET SIZE:
- Legal services: $300B market
- Document review: $40B subsegment, growing 15%/year

PROBLEM SEVERITY:
- Pain: 9/10 (lawyers hate document review)
- Frequency: Every deal, every case
- Actively looking: Yes, firms spend millions

SOLUTION QUALITY:
- 10x better: Yes - hours instead of days
- Why not built: Required recent AI advances

FOUNDER-MARKET FIT:
- I'm a lawyer who became an ML engineer
- I know the pain points competitors miss

EXECUTION:
- Hard startup: requires domain expertise + ML + enterprise sales
- Defensible: data moat, switching costs, relationships

FINAL: Yes, I'd do this for 10 years. Score: 44/50

books.title: How to Be Successful
books.author: Sam Altman (blog)
books.key_takeaway: 13 principles for personal and professional success

podcasts.title: Sam Altman on Lex Fridman
podcasts.key_takeaway: Deep dive on AI, startups, and the future

daily_insights: Ideas are worth nothing. Execution is everything.
The best time to start was yesterday. The second best time is now.
If you're not embarrassed by your first version, you launched too late.
Talk to customers before building. Validate before investing.
Revenue solves all problems. Get to revenue fast.
Your competition is irrelevant. Focus on your customer.
Speed is a feature. Move fast, break things, learn faster.
The best business moats are built on skills others can't copy.
Great businesses solve painful problems for people who can pay.
Think in decades, act in days.
skill_challenges: Validate one business idea by talking to 3 potential customers.
Use ICE scoring on 3 ideas. Pick the highest score to explore.
Write a one-page business model for an idea you have.
Find a problem people complain about. Brainstorm 3 solutions.
Research one successful business in your space. What can you learn?
Calculate the unit economics of a business idea.
Send one cold email to someone you want to learn from.
Identify the 20% of features that would deliver 80% of value.
Map out the minimum viable version of your best idea.
Set a 30-day sprint goal for one project. Write it down.
